rev.diff:
Line 10: Line 10:
Several students were beaten by police wielding [[Baton_(law_enforcement)|riot batons]], apparently for forming a human chain, actively resisting police attempts to clear tents from Upper Sproul Plaza. Police also pulled at least one professor by the hair when she voluntarily surrendered for arrest.
Several students were beaten by police wielding [[Baton_(law_enforcement)|riot batons]], apparently for forming a human chain, actively resisting police attempts to clear tents from Upper Sproul Plaza. Police also pulled at least one professor by the hair when she voluntarily surrendered for arrest.
â
Berkeley Chancellor [[Robert Birgeneau]] and other high ranking administrators later released a statement in which they claimed "It is unfortunate that some protesters chose to obstruct the police by linking arms and forming a human chain to prevent the police from gaining access to the tents. This is not non-violent [[civil disobedience]]." The administrators also claimed "We regret that, given the instruction to take down tents and prevent encampment, the police were forced to use their batons to enforce the policy. We regret all injuries, to protesters and police, that resulted from this effort. The campus's Police Review Board will ultimately determine whether police used excessive force under the circumstances. "
+
Berkeley Chancellor [[Robert Birgeneau]] and other high ranking administrators later released a statement in which they claimed "It is unfortunate that some protesters chose to obstruct the police by linking arms and forming a human chain to prevent the police from gaining access to the tents. This is not non-violent [[civil disobedience]]."
  +   +
UC Police Captain Margo Bennett stated "The individuals who linked arms and actively resisted, that in itself is an act of violence". <ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/10/MNH21LTC4D.DTL]</ref>
  +   +   +   +   +
The administrators also claimed "We regret that, given the instruction to take down tents and prevent encampment, the police were forced to use their batons to enforce the policy. We regret all injuries, to protesters and police, that resulted from this effort. The campus's Police Review Board will ultimately determine whether police used excessive force under the circumstances. "
